Health officials also confirmed that the state’s allotment of vaccine doses from the federal government will increase next week to about 61,000, a more than 8% increase from last week.

New York

Albany: Large arenas and stadiums can soon reopen for sports and entertainment at 10% of their normal capacity under a plan announced by Gov. Andrew Cuomo on Wednesday, despite concern from public health experts about still-high rates of coronavirus infections and the threat of more contagious variants. Cuomo said major stadiums and arenas with a capacity of 10,000 people or more can reopen with limited spectators starting Feb. 23. The Barclays Center, which has about 17,700 seats for basketball games, has already received state approval to reopen Feb. 23 for the Brooklyn Nets’ home game against the Sacramento Kings. And the New York Knicks and New York Rangers said they plan to host about 2,000 fans at every game, starting with Feb. 23 and Feb. 26 games at Madison Square Garden. A New York Yankees spokesperson called Cuomo’s announcement an “encouraging first step.” But CUNY School of Public Health epidemiology professor Denis Nash said the state’s approach lacks a scientific basis when “community prevalence is very high.” He and other public health experts pointed to evidence that COVID-19 spreads more easily indoors and to the risk of people sitting near others who may be cheering or taking masks off while eating.

North Carolina

Raleigh: Gov. Roy Cooper announced Wednesday afternoon that educators and support staff will be eligible to receive a COVID-19 vaccine starting Feb. 24 as part of a staggered rollout of the state’s next phase of distribution. The Democratic governor estimated about 240,000 people would become eligible in two weeks. The group includes child care workers, pre-K to 12th grade principals and teachers at public, private and charter schools, and support staff, such as janitors, bus drivers and cafeteria workers. “Moving to the next phase is good news. The challenge continues to be the very limited supply of the vaccine,” Cooper said. Other groups the state considers “front-line essential workers” will start becoming eligible March 10, though public health officials are still evaluating whether it will prioritize certain subgroups within that population. That group includes manufacturing workers, grocery store clerks, college and university instructors and support staff, farmers, restaurant workers, mail carriers, court workers, elected officials, homeless shelter staff, public health workers, social workers, firefighters, EMS personnel, police officers, public transit workers and several others.

North Dakota

Bismarck: The number of COVID-19 vaccine doses being delivered to North Dakota is increasing. The state will receive a 5% increase in vaccine doses allocated, according to Gov. Doug Burgum. North Dakota will receive 7,500 doses next week, up from 6,900 this week. Also, Thrifty White pharmacies in the state will be getting the vaccine starting this week as part of the Federal Retail Pharmacy Program, the Bismarck Tribune reports. The state’s immunization program manager, Molly Howell, said 16 of the 30 Thrifty White locations in North Dakota have registered to receive the vaccine. According to the company’s vaccination registration website, its pharmacies are inoculating people 65 and older. North Dakotans who want to be vaccinated may need to go somewhere besides their traditional health care provider, Howell said. Pharmacies, local public health departments and private health care providers all are offering vaccines. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, North Dakota’s rate of vaccine doses administered remains among the highest in the country, No. 3, at 17,030 people per 100,000 population.

Ohio

Columbus: The discovery of as many as 4,000 unreported COVID-19 deaths came as the Health Department reconciled an internal death certificate database with a federal database, the state auditor’s office said Thursday. Republican Auditor Keith Faber has been auditing Health Department coronavirus death data since September. But the agency didn’t have access to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s infectious diseases database because of federal health privacy laws, said Matt Eiselstein, Faber’s communications director. “We were never able to make that reconciliation ourselves to come up with those figures,” Eiselstein said. The final audit is expected next month. The Ohio Department of Health said those deaths will now be added to the state’s tally of deaths from the coronavirus during the coming week. Thursday’s coronavirus death toll showed more than 720 deaths, of which 650 come from previously unreported deaths, Gov. Mike DeWine said. “We hope, we believe, that is going to put us back from the track where we actually are,” DeWine said. The Health Department said that “process issues affecting the reconciliation and reporting of these deaths” began in October, with most occurring in November and December.

Oklahoma

Oklahoma City: The first bill signed into law by Gov. Kevin Stitt during the current legislative session allows public bodies to continue meeting virtually as a coronavirus safety precaution. The law signed Wednesday allows public bodies to meet virtually through February 2022 or until the expiration of the governor’s executive emergency order on COVID-19, whichever comes first. “We’ve all heard from constituents, state agencies, local school boards and other public bodies requesting this, and I’m pleased we were able to deliver so quickly,” Stitt said in a statement. The bill by Senate President Pro Tem Greg Treat was passed by the state Senate on Feb. 3 and by the House five days later. “With the signing of this bill, public entities can continue to meet and do so safely until the pandemic is behind us, and the people of Oklahoma maintain access to public meetings at all levels through virtual meetings,” Treat said. Lawmakers last year allowed for virtual meetings, but those provisions expired in November. Rather than convene in a special session, Republican legislative leaders agreed to address the issue at the start of the session.

Oregon

Portland: The week after Christmas, with coronavirus case numbers and hospitalizations soaring, morale was low at Oregon Health & Science University, the state’s largest hospital. Doctors and nurses caring for the most critically ill were burning out just when they were needed the most. Then, the food started coming: hot, delicious, individually wrapped meals from some of the city’s trendiest restaurants, a buffet of cuisines from Chinese to Italian to Lebanese to Southern comfort food. For staffers who only took off their N95 masks once to eat during a 12-hour shift, the meals were more than just food – they were emotional sustenance. “It’s almost like having a weight lifted. It’s like getting a surprise dozen roses or something,” nurse Alice Clark said. “We’re so grateful.” But the meals, paid for by a wellness grant from the Oregon-based insurance fund SAIF, also served another purpose: They kept struggling restaurants afloat. “It’s kept the doors open and a small workforce employed. It’s been the most heartfelt catering we’ve ever done,” said Kiauna Floyd, third-generation owner of Amalfi’s, a Portland institution that’s been serving up Italian cuisine for 62 years. For now, though, meal deliveries to OHSU have dried up with the grant funding, and the program ended Jan. 19. Leaders are hoping for a new funding source to get meals running again soon.

Pennsylvania

Beaver: In the first six weeks of vaccine distribution in Pennsylvania, residents in a handful of counties had no chance of getting inoculated against COVID-19 without leaving their home county. An analysis of state data found that four rural counties didn’t receive any doses in the first six weeks of the bungled rollout, and the majority of doses were sent to health care systems that focused solely on inoculating employees. More than a third of vaccine doses sent out through late January went to three counties: Allegheny, Lehigh and Montgomery, which together are home to 2.4 million people. Removing Philadelphia County from the equation – it receives its vaccine doses directly from the federal government rather than the state – those three counties comprise 21.5% of Pennsylvania’s population. The state uses a formula to determine how to allocate vaccine among counties and providers based on the previous allocation of vaccine, the amount on hand for distribution, the amount administrated, the population, the amount of the population 65 and older, the percent positivity for coronavirus tests and the death rate.

Rhode Island

Pawtucket: The city’s school district, which had largely resisted pressure to bring students back to the classroom, has approved a plan to resume in-person learning for most children. The plan approved Tuesday night by the Pawtucket School Committee calls for bringing back elementary school students March 1, middle school students March 15 and high school students on a hybrid schedule March 29. Only preschoolers, kindergartners and students in special populations had been approved for school in person. The school committee was under pressure from many parents, who rallied last weekend in support of in-person learning. The teachers’ union, which had previously been opposed to in-person instruction, said it now supports in-person learning for elementary students but not high school students.

South Carolina

Greer: While many people grapple with whether to wear two face masks or one, the operator of a local company that’s producing 25,000 three-layer disposable masks every day says one will do. “You don’t have to do that, doubling of a mask,” said Rick Gehricke, chief operating officer of Carolina Facemask and PPE. “If you have a mask certified to international standards, you don’t have to.” Carolina Face Mask & PPE was born more than a year ago from a Greer company founded in 1999 called Advanced Testing Instruments Corp., headed by Tim Ziegenfus. The business provides advanced testing of products in the textile, chemical, plastic, automotive, aerospace, paper, military, medial, foam and packaging industries. When the COVID-19 pandemic hit last March, the company ramped up production of three-ply, Level 1 PPE face masks, and business took off. Spokesperson Katlyn Searcy said with the recent surge in coronavirus cases, many people still don’t realize a small business in Greer is doing its part to fight the pandemic. “People are starting to ask more questions about masks and their effectiveness,” Searcy said. “There are also concerns of more PPE shortages as the curve is trending up again.”

South Dakota

Pierre: Lawmakers are working to memorialize one of their own whom they lost last year to COVID-19. The late Bob Glanzer died in April while still serving as a member of the state House of Representatives after a short battle with coronavirus. Representing District 22, Glanzer was known as “Mr. Huron” for his community involvement in his hometown over his 74 years and a well-respected legislator among not just his fellow Republicans but Democrats as well. And with Gov. Kristi Noem’s pushing legislators to sign off on her plan to set aside $12 million to help the South Dakota State Fair construct a new multipurpose livestock and equestrian facility at the fairgrounds in Huron, House Speaker Spencer Gosch wants to use the opportunity to honor his late friend and colleague’s legacy. “His life was basically servitude to his community, and it shouldn’t go unnoticed,” he said after pitching his plan to state appropriators Tuesday afternoon. Gosch called the situation “fast moving” and said it’s not known what a Glanzer memorial might look like. It could be anything from a sculpture or a plaque to naming the Dakota Events Complex, as the governor has been referring to the project, after him, he said.

Tennessee

Knoxville: Public health officials announced Wednesday that 975 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine that went missing were likely thrown out by accident. Knox County said the state’s Department of Health confirmed the doses were shipped to the region last week, but local officials said they have no record of receiving them. Knox County Health Department Director Dr. Martha Buchanan said that based on GPS data, she believes the box containing the doses was probably discarded by someone who thought they were throwing out dry ice. Due to security reasons, vaccine doses are shipped without any readily identifiable information attached. “It was a kick in the gut for all of us,” Buchanan said through tears. “I apologize. Vaccinating our community is very important to us.” County officials have asked for a state investigation even though Buchanan said there was no indication of foul play. A key question remains why the GPS and temperature monitors attached to the Moderna vaccines did not work, Buchanan said. “Why were we the ones who found this out?” she asked.

Texas

Austwell: The coronavirus pandemic has canceled this year’s flights to count the only natural flock of whooping cranes – the first time in 71 years that crews in Texas couldn’t make an aerial survey of the world’s rarest cranes. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has records of such surveys for every year starting in 1950, Wade Harrell, whooping crane recovery coordinator for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, said in an email Wednesday. The flock breeds in Canada and winters on and around Aransas National Wildlife Refuge in Texas, where the survey is made. Current protocols call for about six flights, each with a pilot and at least two observers – often coming from different parts of the country – in the close quarters of a small plane, Harrell said. “We decided to forgo the aerial survey this winter with COVID-19 cases currently spiking,” he said in a news release. At 5 feet high from their black feet to the little red caps on their heads, whooping cranes are the tallest birds in North America, and their wingspan, at more than 7 feet, is wider than a full-size pickup truck. They mate for life. Only about 825 exist – most of them in the natural flock, which is also the only one that doesn’t need human help to keep its numbers up. Habitat loss and hunting had cut that flock to 15 in 1941.

Utah

Panguitch: Just off this small city’s main road is a small, unassuming building that houses the local office for the Southwest Utah Public Health Department. On a clear, chilly day in early January, dozens of Garfield County residents crowded around the entrance waiting to get the COVID-19 vaccine. The people in line ranged from young to old – teachers to first responders. In the back, Robin McMullin, a supervisor with the health department, was laser-focused as she filled up syringes with the Moderna vaccine. “I feel like it’s liquid gold. I seriously do,” McMullin told KUER-FM. “I don’t want to waste one drop of it.” Garfield County, with just over 5,000 people, has seen nearly 400 cases of COVID-19 – more than one in every dozen people have had the disease. Sheriff Danny Perkins said the spread of the coronavirus really picked up this fall at the county jail. About two thirds of the inmates got it, though there weren’t any serious cases among the prisoners. “But it got out in our staff, and it was devastating,” Perkins said. “There were days that I was ten people down, and when you take ten officers off of an office my size, that’s huge.” As of Feb. 2, nine people in Garfield County had died of COVID-19, making it second in the state for deaths per capita. The community has missed out on big life moments like funerals as well as more casual moments, like getting together at high school basketball games. “It’s a social gathering to get caught up on all the gossip to see how everybody’s doing,” Perkins said. “And it’s been taken away because of this disease.”

Vermont

Burlington: The city has a helpline for seniors who don’t have access to technology or transportation to get the COVID-19 vaccine. The state is now in its third week of immunizing Vermonters 75 and older. The nonprofit Age Well VT is working with the city to help seniors register for an appointment to get their first dose or to get an at-home vaccination, if necessary, WCAX-TV reports. One of the biggest concerns is getting home-bound Vermonters vaccinated, city leaders said. “It may seem to some of us like this information is everywhere, but we know we have not reached all seniors. Even in this very high-risk population, there are still significant number of those who have not yet signed up,” Mayor Miro Weinberger said Wednesday. Black Vermonters also are a large part of the age group who have not been vaccinated. Burlington’s Trusted Community Voices Program is working with the Association of Africans Living in Vermont and other groups to help educate and encourage more people of color to get their first dose, the station reports.

Virginia

Newport News: Christopher Newport University is in the middle of its largest wave of coronavirus cases this school year, and one official put the blame on students not following rules instead of the return to in-person classes. As of Wednesday, 129 students and six employees at Christopher Newport had active cases, The Virginian-Pilot reports. On average, 171 students were in quarantine each day last week, or about 3.5% of the student body. In a letter to students and employees Monday, Kevin Hughes, vice president for student affairs, blamed the rising numbers on students. “What is happening on our campus right now is a stark reminder that individual behavior can have a profound and lasting impact,” Hughes wrote. “When you socialize with little concern, and in some cases reckless disregard, for who it hurts, everybody is impacted.” Some students said the message was condescending and want to see the university take more concrete actions to limit gatherings. Most colleges across the state have dozens or hundreds of active cases. More than 20% of cadets at the Virginia Military Institute are in isolation or quarantine. At William & Mary, cases are also rising sharply, with 79 reported this semester through Tuesday, surpassing last semester’s total in the span of a few weeks.

Washington

Olympia: The state Supreme Court has unanimously rejected a recall effort against the Thurston County sheriff, saying his announcement that he would not criminally enforce the Health Department’s COVID-19 mask mandate was not unreasonable. Resident Arthur West sought to recall Sheriff John Snaza, alleging that Snaza’s news release last June saying his office would not engage in criminal enforcement of the mandate interfered with a lawful order, and a trial court agreed. But the justices overturned that decision Thursday. The Health Department’s order requiring masks in any public setting said violators “may” be subject to criminal penalties. That language gave Snaza discretion in how to enforce the mandate, the court said. The decision noted that Snaza did not generally undermine the mandate: He said his office would continue to work with health officials to educate the public, and he encouraged people to take safety precautions such as wearing masks. Not directly citing or arresting people was reasonable because doing so could risk transmission of the virus, the justices said. They contrasted Snaza’s actions with those of Snohomish County Sheriff Adam Fortney, against whom the court is allowing a recall petition to proceed. Fortney said he had “no intention of carrying out enforcement for a stay-at-home directive” and encouraged business owners to remain open, in violation of the state’s directions.

West Virginia

Charleston: Three events for youth in the state have been canceled for the second consecutive year due to the coronavirus pandemic, officials said. The Make It Shine Earth Day Celebration, West Virginia Youth Environmental Day and state Junior Conservation Camp have all been canceled, the West Virginia Department of Environmental Protection said in a news release. The events were also canceled in 2020 because of COVID-19 restrictions. The Earth Day Celebration is usually held in late April in Charleston, drawing hundreds of grade school-age children for hands-on environmental education, the release said. Youth Environmental Day had been set for May 15 in Ritchie County. Young people are recognized during the event for projects that benefit the environment and their communities. The projects will still be judged and winners recognized. Junior Conservation Camp was scheduled for June 21-25 at Cedar Lakes in Ripley. Nearly 200 campers ages 11 to 14 usually participate.

Wisconsin

Madison: The Legislature’s Republican-controlled budget committee approved a bill Wednesday that would cut taxes by $540 million by the middle of 2023, largely by eliminating taxes on federal loans to businesses to help them through the pandemic. The full Legislature could vote to pass it as soon as Tuesday. Democrats on the budget committee argued that the bill cost too much and was another handout to businesses that took the loans but still flourished during the pandemic. “We’re punching a big hole in the budget,” Rep. Evan Goyke said. “We can direct our relief in a more targeted, more efficient manner.” Republicans countered that the bill brings state tax code in line with federal code. “This isn’t everyone’s dream tax bill,” said Rep. Mark Born, a committee co-chair. “This bill matches federal law. Of course it’s not perfect.” Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat, would have to sign the bill for the tax cut to take effect. Asked whether Evers would veto the measure, his spokeswoman, Britt Cudaback, responded with a statement from the governor saying he would keep doing everything he can to support small businesses during the pandemic.

Wyoming

Casper: The Coal Creek coal mine says it will shut down, making it the second mine in the Powder River Basin to announce this year that it’s closing. St. Louis, Missouri-based Arch Resources Inc., owner of the Wyoming mine, made the announcement Tuesday as the company transitions away from thermal coal generation toward coking coal, a type of coal used to make steel and other products, the Casper Star-Tribune reports. Arch Resources said it plans to wind down operations at the mine near Gillette and begin cleaning up the site over the next two years. The company said it lost $78.5 million in the final quarter of last year. The Coal Creek mine produced about 2 million tons of its lower heat value coal last year, 73% less than in 2018. The mines in the Powder River Basin produce about 40% of the nation’s coal, but production has declined in part because of a push for natural gas and renewable energy. Montana’s Decker coal mine, also in the Powder River Basin, closed last month. Production losses from coal companies have led to rising unemployment and worsening state revenue shortfalls. The coronavirus pandemic also lowered demand for coal.

From USA TODAY Network and wire reports

search_result.title: No place to call home
search_result.text:
Casey Blake, and Erin Brethauer

Asheville Citizen-Times

Story by Casey Blakecblake@citizen-times.com

Photography by Erin Brethauerebrethau@citizen-times.com

………………………………………………………………………….

Shane Hopkins' children have never slept on the streets. They've never spent a night under a bridge, never slept in his car.

They show up to school looking like most every other child in Buncombe County. But they carry an invisible weight: They didn't have a bed to sleep in or room to call their own for half of the just-finished school year.

Skylar, 12, has learned to do her hair and brush her teeth in school bathrooms. "There are no mirrors in (school) in the bathroom, so sometimes I have to walk all the way to the gym," she said with a shrug. "Whatever, it's annoying."

She called in sick to school one day because she was awoken by her brother's tantrums, 3 feet from one another on the floor of the double wide in Fairview she shared with eight people.

Luke, 9, and Logan, his autistic twin brother, learned to ration snacks and sleep on loveseats not quite as long as their quickly growing bodies.

By the school system's standards, they were homeless. But by federal housing standards, they were never homeless enough.

By living "doubled up" with other families and friends, they have lived in an impossible gray area of social services, one that 78 percent of all homeless families in Buncombe County share.

They are part of the invisible but rapidly growing population that won't show up in optimistic unemployment reports or state budgets.

And what happened to the Hopkins family "could happen to you at any moment," Shane Hopkins said. "I would never have believed it, two or three years ago. But it can."

Hopkins' children account for three of at least 750 schoolchildren in Buncombe County who lived in and out of homelessness last year. That number has grown steadily over the past five years, more than doubling since the height of the Great Recession in 2009.

Children are the new frontier in homelessness, the only subpopulation of homeless people that has actually grown in recent years.

One in five American children nationally is now living in poverty, giving the United States the highest child poverty rate of any developed nation except for Romania.

North Carolina has slowly climbed to the top of this national trend, consistently ranked as one of the 10 states with the highest population of homeless children in the nation.

At the center of most political and funding debates surrounding homelessness is the image of out-of-work single mothers, disabled veterans and mentally ill or drug-addicted adults. They eventually lead to the exchange of phrases such as "personal responsibility" and "entitlement."

Children are rarely the face of that debate, though they have the most to lose from a life without stable housing.

"These families are unknown, unheard, unseen," Buncombe County Schools homelessness coordinator Luke Heller said. "They're invisible. How do you advocate for children who are politically invisible? You can't. Especially if we don't call them homeless."

The family

When asked if he considers himself homeless, Shane Hopkins winces, taking a long pause.

"Yeah," he says. "Yeah. We're homeless. What an incredibly strange thing to say. We're homeless people."

Five years ago the Hopkins family lived in a four-bedroom Colonial in the foothills of the Poconos mountains in New Jersey, a little over an hour from the Manhattan firm where Shane worked.

His three kids, twins Luke and Logan, then 3, and Skylar, age 7, had their own rooms on five acres surrounded by farmland.

"It was beautiful," Shane said. "We had a three-car garage. We lived a really nice, comfortable life."

His wife, Dana, was a stay-at-home mom. They chose their home based on the best school district and an area with clean air, Shane said.

"We struggled a little bit to meet our mortgage some months, but it never got scary," he said. "We were putting a little bit away. We were careful, we thought. I had a 401(k). We were planning for our future, and it looked really bright."

A few months after they bought that home, Shane got the call that his job in software was being moved off-shore, and he was being laid off.

The next year, Dana died unexpectedly, and things unraveled quickly after that.

"You have a $5,000 a month mortgage and a car payment and the cost of therapy for an autistic child," Shane said. "In three months, your 401(k) is gone, there are no jobs. ... It happens in the blink of an eye."

Family homelessness is what insiders call a "lagging indicator" of an economic downturn. Families, more than individuals, will fight and scrape together every last option before allowing children to sleep on the streets or lose their homes.

"Families generally don't drop as immediately into homelessness as individuals," said Heather Dillahsaw, coordinator for the Asheville Buncombe Homeless Initiative. "Children tend to couch surf more easily. People don't want children sleeping outside."

Hopkins maxed out every credit card he had, borrowed money here and there, and moved the family into smaller rented homes and fell behind in rent. They had three or four credit cards with four or five thousand dollars each on them, he said. They were evicted from their last home.

After the eviction they visited their last resort, moving in with an old friend of Shane's. The home is a doublewide in Fairview, at the top of a mountain so steep most two-wheel drive vehicles can't scale it. The family has survived for the last year on the children's survivor benefits and Social Security from his 64-year-old mother, Janice, who has lived with the family since they came to North Carolina to help with the kids.

"A parent will throw every resource they have at keeping their children sheltered," Heller said. "They'll max out every card, borrow from high-interest lenders, do everything they can think of to keep from ending up in the shelter or on the streets, so it takes longer for them to fall."

"It's not the same as being on the streets, I know that," Hopkins said. "But it feels like we're not far from that. Like we're a moment away from it. And you can't tell me children don't feel that."

"I know people will judge me, I know they will look at me in an adverse way," he said. "I just hope people will understand that this could happen to anyone."

Skylar

Skylar is strikingly beautiful at 12, with long, wavy blonde hair and huge blue eyes. She's never without boys surrounding her at school.

She's adventurous and often disarmingly uninhibited for a middle school girl. She is as excited by a sparkly pair of sneakers as she is to capture a salamander for her vast collection of slimy creek creatures in the family's homemade aquarium.

She's most at ease in the spotlight, a talented performer. In her previous lives in St. Louis and Florida, Skylar was a cheerleader, a dancer and even did some modeling.

She's given that up in the past year, mostly due to the challenge of getting up and down the mountain in Shane's Oldsmobile, which breaks down several times a month.

"I've always had a big room," she says. "I've never had to share a room.

"I'm used to having friends come over, and my dad would drive me to the movies," Skylar said. "But I can't anymore, because…" and she trails off.

In Fairvew, Skylar slept on a pad of blankets on the floor in a corner between the kitchen and living rooms.

Her corner of the room was unmistakable as the territory of a tween girl, strewn with a tornado of brightly colored tank tops, sparkly accessories and nail polish.

But discovering makeup, boys and coming of age as a pre-teen girl has looked different for her than it has for many of her peers.

On many occasions the family would run out of water, sometimes for just a day but often for several in a row. The double-wide they shared wasn't built for eight people who cook and take showers and baths, and the well water ran low or completely diminished for days on end.

On those days, Skylar would walk to a neighbor's house for showers or sneak into school bathrooms before classes to brush her teeth or do her hair.

"Sometimes I have to brush my hair and stuff at school, which is stupid," Skylar said with a roll of her eyes. "And I floss there. I have to floss all the time — I'm crazy about flossing."

Sleeping has been a challenge for Skylar, positioned in the middle of the trailer and therefore in the middle of her siblings' every move.

Logan often wakes in the night or struggles to fall asleep, and Skylar has no place to escape when he has a screaming fit or tantrum.

"Sometimes I just lock myself in the bathroom," she said. "I just have nowhere to be."

Skylar says she doesn't feel "homeless," and discusses the idea of people who don't have homes in the third person, even when describing her own living situation.

"I think of homeless as people who live in a box, or people who don't have a house like hobos," she said with a nervous laugh. "But it's also people who share a house. It doesn't have to be for money reasons, it could just be like people looking for a house.

"Here you can find a house pretty cheap," she said. "But utilities and bills and stuff are pretty expensive, so it can be really hard to do."

Shane insists the children aren't too affected by the family's financial struggles. But part of him knows they are.

Luke, when asked how he likes being a twin, said, "It's pretty cool. It's not something not many other people have, like you get to be something special."

"I just wish Logan wasn't autistic sometimes, though," Luke said, characteristically blunt. "It's harder without much money because he doesn't have the stuff he used to and you can't really go anywhere when he's all upset."

"They feel it, but it amazes me how the children never lose hope," Shane said. "Their grandmother and I will be talking about how to scrape together money for food, and one of them will just pop up and say, 'It'll be fine dad. It'll work out.'

"Their hopes and dreams have not been affected by this, and that gives me a lot of strength," he said.

"Of course the children are very astute, they're more perceptive than you realize," he said. "I just try to shield them as much as possible.

"But you can't cover it when we're rationing food, when you don't have water," Shane said. "How do you explain to them why they have to eat lunch at school no matter what, because we can't afford to feed them lunch here?"

Defining child homelessness

According to recent data from the Department of Education, more than 1.1 million students in the United States in grades K-12 were homeless in the 2011-12 school year.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, the federal authority over housing issues, defines chronic homelessness as having been homeless four times in a three-year period or for one full year or longer, and having a disabling condition.

Asheville has done well in addressing those numbers — in fact the chronically homeless have been nearly eradicated in Buncombe County. This year's Point-in-Time Count count showed only 47 people still experiencing chronic homelessness, down 84 percent from 293 chronically homeless individuals identified in 2005.

"These (chronically homeless) are people who live in the system, who use the majority of resources so we have to focus on that demographic," said Emily Ball, development director of Homeward Bound. "Our job now is to focus on a different sub-population — the family — which is something we're still learning about. That's really the next frontier for us."

But a major challenge in addressing that new frontier is defining what child homelessness even is.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development standards, the definitions by which more state and local homelessness coordinators like Dillashaw operate, are much stricter than those used by local school districts.

HUD standards require that a family be completely without shelter, living in a car or on the street or other environments, "unfit for human habitation," to be defined as homeless.

Only people who are "literally homeless" according to HUD's definition are counted in the Point-in-Time Count, the leading national data set on homeless children and adults in America.

This means that on the night of the count, those children have to be residing in emergency shelter, including domestic violence shelters, in transitional housing for homeless persons who originally came from the streets or emergency shelters, or in places not meant for human habitation, like cars, parks, abandoned buildings, streets or campgrounds.

Shane and his family have never qualified for that count.

"The most vulnerable are the literally homeless," Dillashaw said. "We have to target resources where people are the most at-risk and most vulnerable."

"If we had all kinds of money, that would be different," Dillashaw said. "Unfortunately those people are more at risk. I think those definitions are where they need to be."

Buncombe County Schools operates under a very different definition of what constitutes homelessness in children than those set by HUD, and therefore city or county organizations.

The standard for school homelessness services are based on the McKinney-Vento Act, which defines homeless children and youth as "individuals who lack a fixed, regular, and adequate night-time residence."

The term includes children who are sharing the housing of other persons because of loss of housing, economic hardship, or similar reasons; living in motels, hotels, trailer parks, or campgrounds; and living in a primary night-time residence not used as a "regular sleeping accommodation."

The overwhelming majority of the homeless families Buncombe County Schools serves, about 78 percent, are "doubled up," or sharing housing with another family.

"They often have heat (and) water (and) are sheltered, clothed, clean and fed," Heller said. "To the naked eye that would not be perceived as homeless, and indeed they have a roof over their heads. It's amazing how often families work together to support themselves and each other. This is a culture that's somewhat misunderstood and in the shadows. They're afraid to be seen."

To Heller, Shane Hopkins' family more than qualifies as homeless, but their case would never make it to Dillashaw's desk.

"The school definition of 'doubled up' is good, because essentially that definition is about prevention," Dillashaw said. "But we do not call them homeless."

The gap between these definitions makes for significantly different data sets. According to the latest Point-in-Time counts, the county reported a total of 58 homeless children.

At last count in Buncombe County, there were 556 students in the county district and 201 in the city who were identified as homeless. Heller said the best national estimates are that the number of identified students likely accounts for about a third of students who might qualify if identified.

"Ending homelessness doesn't end poverty," Dillashaw said. "When we house people in Asheville, we're housing them into poverty.

"What we're trying to do is get them more stable to be more well and more healthy," she said, "but we're not ending poverty for them by any stretch. It's a different level of poverty, but just another level."

Story by John Boyle jboyle@citizen-times.com

Photography by Erin Brethauer ebrethau@citizen-times.com



When it comes to getting into affordable housing and out of the world of homelessness, the word "competition" likely doesn't jump to mind.

But it should.

"When you have vacancy rates that are really, really low and such little affordable housing in our community on top of that, it makes it very competitive to get into the market anywhere," said Brian Alexander, executive director of Homeward Bound, the Asheville nonprofit agency that helps get low-income people into housing. "When you have credit issues and criminal history issues on top of that — and some of our families have issues with transportation on top of that — it can be very difficult."

And these challenges are affecting families disproportionately. At least 750 schoolchildren in Buncombe County were identified as homeless last year, making families the only sub-population of homeless people to have grown in recent years.

Compounding the red tape and short housing supply is the mountain economy and housing market, one that relies heavily on tourism jobs that pay lower wages in a beautiful area where home prices and rents are higher than other regions. That often adds up to housing being just out of reach for low-income and even moderate income families.

In 2013, nearly one-half of all renters in Asheville and just less than 40 percent of homeowners fell under the category of "cost-burdened," which are those paying more than 30 percent of income for a place to live, according to U.S. Census Bureau figures for a five-year span ending in 2013.

That's if they can get in. Most housing agencies derive their funding from federal government money, and with those come a long list of requirements and guidelines those agencies must follow, including background and credit checks and whether they've been evicted before.

Hitting the hurdles

Shane Hopkins feels like he's gotten a personal look inside that bureaucratic machine over the past few years.

Five years ago the Hopkins family lived in a four-bedroom home in New Jersey, but the the loss of his high-paying software job and the unexpected death of his wife shortly thereafter started a downward spiral that led to Hopkins and his three children staying in a friend's home in Fairview. After arriving in Asheville last August, they became part of the de facto homeless, although Hopkins diligently searched for housing.

"We definitely hit some of those hurdles," Hopkins said. "What we came up against in North Carolina was with the programs to help people in general — and not just in housing — there were a lot of programs in place that were funded by the government or different types of organizations. We found out a lot of the programs were really facades to kind of check off boxes or to create compliance of other broader programs that brought in the money. There was a person on the phone but no real meat and potatoes behind the the person on the phone."

With three kids in tow, 9-year-old twins Luke and Logan and 12-year-old daughter Skylar, Hopkins was desperate to get them out of the friend's house and into their own. The first step he took was looking at homes for rent on Craigslist.

"The first thing they want is a credit check and background report," Hopkins said, adding that he has no criminal background but did have an eviction on a previous house. "With the credit check you have to be creative in how you approach it. Sometimes being up front about it is the way to go; sometimes you've got to use a diversionary tactic, maybe some cash in hand, or a story. You've got to be really, really creative in thinking, 'How can I get this woman past this point of doing background check and credit report, and focus on how it would be valuable having me as a tenant?"

With a family counting on him, Hopkins said he was out there "fighting" to find a place and working with a local nonprofit. Still, "with 90 percent of the places we looked at, we never got past (the credit check and background report)," he said.

The eviction was poison to most potential renters. The options that remain, Hopkins said, are renting from people "who don't check or don't care," and that usually translates into lower quality properties with a lot of problems, or less tech-savvy owners who go on their gut feeling.

Ultimately, a local church, Trinity of Fairview Baptist Church, stepped up for Hopkins, his children and his mother, who lives with them. Just before Christmas, church members had found out about his plight through the Buncombe County Schools homeless coordinator and offered to supply Christmas gifts.

By happenstance, a church member who'd just lost her tenants met Hopkins outside the church's toy room and offered to rent the house to him, without a background check. His children receive Social Security survivors benefits and his mother is on disability, an income that totals $2,700 a month.

That put the $900 rent firmly within reach.

"In 10, 15 minutes we went from having nothing to having a truckload of Christmas gifts for my kids and a place to live," Hopkins said. "All this happened in a space of 15 minutes, after a year of trying. The goodwill and good faith of people in the community, they fixed the problem. They saw something they weren't going to stand for and they fixed it."

Lots of effort, huge demand

In the Asheville area, we have no shortage of agencies, nonprofits and other groups trying to fix the problem of affordable housing. But we also have an enormous number of people in need.

In Buncombe County, for every 100 extremely low-income renter households — those earning less than $17,500 annually — there were only 31 affordable rental units available in 2012, according to the Urban Institute, a Washington, D.C.-based, nonpartisan think tank that conducts economic and social policy research. With a population of about 245,000, the county had 10,308 households that met that qualification but only 3,214 affordable rental units available.

In 2000, Buncombe had 5,427 households that met that income qualification and 2,472 affordable rental units available.

Asheville and Buncombe County have made a stronger effort to build affordable housing than several over comparably-sized cities in the region, according to a recent report the city commissioned, called the "Affordable Housing Scorecard." The city and county have sunk $17.4 million into developments between 2007-13, with money coming from federal, city and county funding.

During that time, the Asheville Housing Trust Fund accounted for $1.7 million in spending, while $3.6 million came through Buncombe. Those efforts resulted in 461 rental units and 223 homes on the market between 2007-13.

The N.C. Housing Finance Agency, which funnels bond funds, and state and federal dollars into affordable housing, notes that since 1974, it has helped finance just more than 4,200 homes and apartments in Buncombe County and has provided 5,100 households with rental assistance.

Mountain Housing Opportunities, an Asheville nonprofit dedicated to building affordable housing, adds 50-60 apartments to the local market every year. But demand always outstrips supply for their units, which offer income-based rents that are typically half the cost of market rate housing.

For example, in 2010, MHO offered up for lease 60 units in its new Glen Rock Apartments in the River Arts District. They got more than 1,000 applications.

Cindy Visnich Weeks, MHO's director of community investments, said they do have to follow federal guidelines on credit and background checks for potential renters, but that's not the major hurdle to securing housing, as she sees it.

"To me the major hurdle is just finding a living wage job," Weeks said. "You can't solve the problems of the economy with housing."

The average apartment rent for the Asheville market in 2013 was $864 a month, just $10 a month less than Charlotte, according to the Charlotte apartment research firm Real Data. Rents have steadily risen in Buncombe, increasing from $690 a month in December 2004 to $839 in 2012, a 22 percent jump.

In December 2004, the average mortgage was $878 a month, increasing to $1,028 in 2009, then dropping to $979 last year. That amounts to a 12 percent increase over the span. At the same time, wages for many have remained stagnant, despite low unemployment, with the average weekly income in Buncombe County rising from $535 a week to $690 from 2001-13.

But factoring in inflation, weekly wages actually have declined, coming in at $524, according to Syneva Economics.

Weeks recalled a recent meeting about helping people get in affordable housing that she attended that included bank, housing and credit officials.

"I said, 'You can all outline individual causes of why people don't qualify, but it comes down to we have a tourism-based economy that pays low wages and has very high housing costs," Weeks said.

"Sometimes, when I feel cynical, I feel like we're propping up employers to pay less than a living wage."

In Hopkins' case, he said he arrived in Asheville last year with $60 in his wallet and no job prospects. He had worked in IT for the American Association of Orthodontists in St. Louis and had an extensive background in the field but said he came back to work too soon after his wife's death and "couldn't possibly have handled it well."

He was let go, landing in Asheville. With a small Internet startup under his belt right now, he's pulling in a "few hundred dollars a month," income he hopes to grow.

Lingering problems, no simple solution

At the Housing Authority of the City of Asheville, low income is the standard. The problem is supply.

Occupancy for the authority's 1,531 public housing units in 11 developments hovers at 99 percent, while another 1,500 units in the Section 8 apartment program stays at 96-97 percent, according to Executive Director Gene Bell. That Section 8 number is a little misleading, as the voucher program was closed in 2011 because the program has 2,000 people on the waiting list.

Funded through the Department of Housing of Urban Development, the Housing Authority has to adhere to federal guidelines. They do criminal background checks on all tenants but not credit checks.

"Some of the biggest hurdles we see are the person may have had previous tenancy with us and left under unfavorable circumstances," said Noele Tackett, resident selection coordinator with HACA.

Anyone with a felony conviction within the last five years will be denied housing, and misdemeanor drug charges within that time frame may have a similar result, although those cases are looked at individually, Bell said. Anyone with a methamphetamine production conviction or status as registered sex offenders are banned for life.

Bell, who also served on the Asheville City Schools Board of Education, says the affordable housing issues breaks down into three segments, as he sees it:

The public housing residents HACA serves, who have to earn 80 percent of the median national income or less to qualify.

The working poor where folks are making at or near minimum wage and struggle to make ends meet.

Entry level workers such as police, firefighters and teachers for whom "affordability is a challenge."

While the Asheville area is known as a retirement mecca awash in trendy restaurants and golf courses, affordable housing is an issue that dominates the landscape of working people.

"I think it's bigger than we want to realize it is and even confess that it is," Bell said. "But affordable housing here is a major issue. I don't know of anybody working any harder than Asheville to try to address it, but the median rent and the median income, that gap is getting wider all the time."

Alexander, at Homeward Bound, said Asheville has made great strides in attacking homelessness, but the community still struggles with the issue, partly because of the income issue. They deal with a lot of families that are at 30-50 percent of the median income.

A rule of thumb is that affordable housing in a given market should not constitute more than 30 percent of a family's or individual's income.

"Most people we work with aren't able to get into fair market housing without paying more than 30 percent of their incomes," Alexander said. "A lot of our people are paying 50 percent or more."

Child care is expensive, and that impacts affordability, too, Alexander said. Many also struggle with transportation issues — being able to afford a car and insurance.

Besides a lack of housing and income issues, the biggest problem they encounter with placing families in housing is eviction. Some rental companies or agencies might overlook some credit issues, and they're willing to bend when medical conditions cause financial woes, but eviction is different.

"Once someone has had eviction, a lot of landlords and management companies won't even touch them," Alexander said, adding that they often refer such people to the financial assistance nonprofit OnTrack Financial Education & Counseling. "An eviction, that can take seven years to get that off your credit report. That's a long time. So then you have to be very creative. We're also very upfront."

Bill Murdoch, executive director of Eblen Charities, which has a housing assistance program, said they helped 1,757 families last year to stay in their home or find one, and they provided utilities and bill assistance to another 11,800. The charity disbursed $345,000 for housing help and another $1.5 million to help people with utilities and bills.

The idea is to help people stay in their homes so they don't become homeless. Once someone becomes homeless, they then have to accrue security and utility deposits before trying to rent again, a huge obstacle when you're already down.

Still, it's an uphill struggle in a long, slow economic recovery.

"I don't think there's any one cause for it, and I don't think there's any one answer," Murdoch said. "What's important is to be able to keep people in their homes."

For his part, Hopkins said his time of homelessness and struggling with various bureaucracies has been "exhausting and enlightening." He knows agencies are trying, but one lesson he's taken away is that we have to take care of each other.

"In the end, it's the community that fixes stuff, not the government," he said.

Families living in cars. Families camping, then driving to a bus stop so the other kids won't see them emerging from the woods. Families living in abandoned buildings, trading the heat and running water that comes with living in a shelter for the privacy and lesser exposure to dangerous people.

These are the families who Luke Heller has worked with on a daily basis over the last three years as the Buncombe County Schools homeless students liaison.

They aren't necessarily the norm; in fact a majority of the students he works with are living in less severe circumstances. But there are enough to keep him up at night, and enough that the school system is struggling to keep up with even identifying them, much less getting them the resources they need.

"Every year we see some some pretty incredible, pretty severe circumstances," Heller said. "It amazes me, still. Children living in cars, abandoned buildings and who lack running water or electricity. These kids are on the buses with other students, and most people have absolutely no idea."

Public schools are often on the front lines of child homelessness, identifying them and connecting their families with resources before social services even knows they exist.

Teachers and schools staff are trained to spot the signs — children wearing the same clothes for several days, seeming hungry or especially tired. Once identified, they're referred to Heller's office. He then connects them with community resources and makes arrangements for transportation, which has traditionally been a huge hurdle for families who may be sleeping in a different home — and a different school district — every night or week.

Schools operate under a very different definition of what constitutes homelessness in children than those standards set by the federal housing authority, HUD, and therefore city or county officials.

HUD standards require that a family be completely without shelter, living in a car or on the street or other environments "unfit for human habitation" to be defined as homeless.

The standard for school homelessness services are based on the McKinney-Vento Act, which defines homeless children and youth as "individuals who lack a fixed, regular, and adequate night-time residence."

At last count in Buncombe County, there were 556 students in the county district and 201 in the city who were identified as homeless. Heller said the best national estimates are that the number of identified students likely accounts for about a third of students who might qualify if identified.

The overwhelming majority of the homeless families Buncombe County Schools serves — about 78 percent — are "doubled up," or sharing housing with another family. Last year, 65 students were identified as living in shelters, 16 were completely unsheltered, and 39 were living in motels.

Heller changed the way the district asks parents how they are living, a move that has likely contributed to a significant bump in the number of students they identify as homeless.

Instead of asking a parent "are you homeless?" on intake forms and surveys, Buncombe County schools also asks if a family is sharing housing with another, and if they have a permanent place of residence.

"As a parent, it can be hard to admit that your family is in trouble," Heller said. "No parent wants to come forward and say 'Hey, we're homeless. Look at us.' Asking for help is incredibly hard, and parents fear losing their children if they admit they don't have shelter for them."

"We have identified so many families who won't call themselves homeless, who just can't bring themselves to check that box, but who are living in some pretty severe circumstances."

The faces behind those circumstances vary widely, Heller said.

"Especially in this area, it's not uncommon at all with national forests for parents to be camping, then driving their kids to school because they don't want their kids at bus stops coming right out of the woods," Heller said. "I've had families camping out at the end of dead-end roads, in forests, in woods behind big commercial buildings."

"I've worked with families living in abandoned buildings that used to be a game room that have no showers, heat or bathrooms, a single mother fleeing domestic violence camping with a middle school boy. Families living in cars."

This year Heller met, a high school-age child who had been out of school for six months and his mother, who had been living between motels and in their car. He met them in a big box store parking lot, sitting with them in their car in 30-degree weather.

"When their monthly check ran out, they would live in their cars," Heller said. "That was their norm."

"I just kept thinking, I can barely stand to sit in here. How are you sleeping like this?"

Another family he's worked with lived in the shell of their trailer, which had had burned down months earlier.

"They ran an extension cord from a neighbor's trailer and cooked with a coffee pot," he said. "They didn't think they had another option."

The immediate supports put them up in a hotel for a couple of days, he said, "But then what? They had no other option than to move back into that trailer."

Unaccompanied homeless youth, or students who have no parents in the picture and aren't living within the foster care system, are another significant demographic Heller sees. Of the 556 students identified as homeless last year, 96 of those were unaccompanied homeless youth.

"I worked with one boy who could not return to family," he said, adding that some students are forced to leave their homes because they pose a danger to siblings, or their homes pose a danger to them. "So he slept in in a grocery store parking lot in his car, and just worked to support himself."

"Immediately, the impact is basic. It's food insecurity. It's a lack of access to necessary resources for health care, the impact of dangerous housing situations," Heller said.

"The long-term impact is a lifelong experience of homelessness in some form or another," he said. "It's not that someone sees it and thinks, 'I want to live that way, too.' It's a lifestyle, that they just settle for this and become resigned to that way of life. That's one of the longest reaching impacts that we have to stop.'"

Story by Casey Blakecblake@citizen-times.com

Photography by Erin Brethauerebrethau@citizen-times.com

The morning starts in silence.

Zahmari, 6, and her sister Aaliyah, 8, wake to the sudden glare of industrial fluorescent lighting, about two feet above the top bunks they share with their 2-year old brother, Lavarion, their mom, Tiana, and their infant brother, Lavar.

It's 5 a.m. They have 90 minutes to be out of the room where they've slept since September, where they won't be allowed back until later that night.

Without a word, they climb down the metal ladders and groggily start what will be a series of adult tasks they take on throughout the day.

Zahmari goes straight to the baby bottles resting on a rusted TV stand, where they also store the baby's shoes, a broken TV and an old VCR. It's the only piece of furniture in the room, other than the five bunk beds shared by the 10 women and children living in it.

She quietly counts off the ounces, pouring the contents of a plastic bottle of water into the baby's bottle.

"One, two, three, four… stop," she whispers to herself, then scoops out the powdered formula they keep in a container on the TV stand.

Aaliyah works next to her sister, her eyes still swollen from sleep, cracking open one of the four, 18-gallon plastic storage bins where they keep their every belonging, pulling out a bright yellow and orange dress she's been waiting to wear all week.

It matches a new pair of rubber flip-flops she got just yesterday, still with their tags on, laid out at the end of her bunk the night before.

She holds her dress up to them, as if to make sure it hadn't changed colors overnight, then pulls her toothbrush out of a plastic bag of brushes her family shares. She leaves for the bathroom they share with two dozen other women, where her family will have 15 minutes of private time to wash and get ready for the day.

Zahmari stays behind to help her mom. "I am the pick-up robot," she murmurs in an automated voice, miming with bent elbows and flat hands, as she picks up binkies, tiny shoes and barrettes her siblings left behind. The room has to be spotless, otherwise her mother could be written up by shelter staff.

Zahmari and Aaliyah are two of more than 750 school children identified as homeless in Buncombe County last year, a number which has only grown since the height of the Great Recession.

The girls have lived with their family in the Western Carolina Rescue Ministries shelter on Patton Avenue downtown since September — for almost an entire school year.

As they enter the main shelter downstairs, they take their places in the chapel, where everyone waits to be fed.

They stand next to one man, still reeking of alcohol from the night before. Another covered in tattoos and a torn shirt winks as Zahmari passes him. She quickly turns away, knowing better than to talk to strangers, even though she's surrounded by them constantly.

The girls are careful not to call the room they sleep in home. Unlike their brothers, they remember what a home is — mostly as a place where they ran into their parents' room on Sunday mornings and jumped on the bed until someone made them pancakes. It's been almost nine months, but they remember the difference.

"People are nice here, and my bed is comfortable," Zahmari says with a shrug. "But I just miss being a family sometimes."

The family is one of a growing number in Buncombe County entering shelters, living doubled up with other families and otherwise living without permanent housing.

Families and children are what experts call a lagging indicator of an economic downturn, the new frontier in fighting homelessness.

Children are the only sub-population of homeless people that has actually grown in recent years, a trend shelter workers and others working to address homelessness have watched with concern.

"We do everything we can to make it comfortable for the kids, to make it like a home," Pastor Michael Woods, director of the shelter, said. "But it makes you sick seeing all these kids in here ... just makes you sick. They shouldn't have to be here. And we can't keep up, the way things have been going. It's growing too fast."

Sheltered kids

Tiana Jackson cried for hours the night she and her partner of seven years, Lavar Bailey, decided they had to move their three children into the shelter.

She was pregnant at the time with her fourth child, Lavar II, who came home from the hospital to the shelter in March.

Both parents were working fast food jobs at the time, barely making ends meet for years. They lived paycheck to paycheck each month, but they made it work.

Then, slowly, they both saw the number of hours their employers would allow them to work start waning, and eventually those paychecks got too small to make rent.

After falling three months behind, they were evicted from their home in Weaverville. They lived in a motel for more than a month, but eventually realized they couldn't afford even that for much longer, and came to the shelter until they could get back on their feet.

"I was afraid of everything that first night," Tiana said. "Of exposing them to all these people, of them being afraid. I was afraid they would feel ashamed. I felt ashamed. And I was worried [Lavar] would leave because we hit this rock bottom."

But he didn't leave, and the two have since found a way to juggle an impossible Rubiks cube of work schedules and child care, parenting their four children from different floors of the shelter.

Tiana works full-time at KFC, taking as many hours as she can whenever she can. Most days she works the day shift, getting home just before Lavar has to work nights at a Pizza Hut in Weaverville.

On the nights he can't get a ride home, Lavar will walk more than seven miles back to the shelter, so he can be there when the kids wake up and Tiana can go to work.

Lavar spends most days taking care of the kids, usually with baby Lavar strapped to his chest in a Bjorn and Lavarion, or Boo Boo as the family calls him, holding his hand or tugging at his pants.

During the school year, he met the girls at the bus stop every day with a big bear hug and a high five. The girls say they hated getting dropped off at the shelter at first — they were embarrassed. But they're more used to it now.

Their summer days are filled mostly alternating between afternoons at the downtown library and Aston Park, both of which they can walk to.

Last week, the family rode the bus for more than an hour, waiting for the shelter to open for lunch. As it is, they're stuck in the shelter from 5 p.m. to after 6 the next morning, so they take every opportunity to get away.

The girls are not Lavar's biological children, but you wouldn't know it from watching them.

He already worries about the day the girls will start dating and wonders what kind of parents they'll be. He takes every opportunity to teach them, making them spell the names of things they see in the park and practice counting.

"I try to teach them to be gentle with their brothers and how to take care of them," he said, watching as Aaliyah pushed her brother in the stroller, in a tiny circle at the park.

"I want them to be good moms and to be with good men."

The girls take joy in little pleasures, from drawing elaborate scenes with the ballpoint pens they borrow from office staff at the shelter desk to balancing on the wooden beams marking the parking lot around the shelter.

They alternate seamlessly between moments of stark adulthood and the universal silliness of being a little girl, making baby bottles for their little brother in the park, taking breaks only to giggle uncontrollably when one of them says "yaybe" instead of "baby."

Tiana jokes that Aaliyah is "Mom No. 2" to her siblings.

Each night, the children have to say goodbye to their daddy, who has to sleep with the general population downstairs, apart from the women and children in the upstairs wing. Some nights the parting is peaceful, others Lavarion will scream and cry, yelling that he doesn't want to leave his daddy. Lavar has never seen where his children have slept the last nine months.

Tiana and the kids have to be upstairs by 5 p.m. and are not allowed to leave again until the next morning. They make the best of it, singing to the baby and playing with the small collection of toys in the shared living room upstairs.

Tiana's darkest moments seem to come as she's stuffing the family's things back into the four plastic bins the five of them share. It's as if her every frustration with the family's lives lives in those bins. Every T-shirt, bottle of lotion, every toy and book — they all have to fit.

Ending the cycle

The Jackson-Bailey family hits almost every mark on the long list of factors that make a family vulnerable to housing insecurity.

The family has applied for public housing but has been denied. Even with their combined wages working as many hours as they can get, they still fall well below the marker of "cost-burdened," which are those paying more than 30 percent of income for a place to live.

In 2013, nearly one-half of all renters in Asheville and just less than 40 percent of homeowners fell under that category.

Both have poor credit, primarily from unpaid bills and credit cards Tiana says her parents took out in her name when she was too young to know the difference.

Lavar has a record — nonviolent crimes from when he was a teenager — but a record, nonetheless.

He's applied for a dozen jobs closer to town, where he can work more hours and walk to and from work, but if the fact that he doesn't have reliable transportation doesn't get in the way, his record does.

Both of these — poor credit and criminal history — can be crippling to accessing housing, children or not.

"It's almost better to have a criminal history than to have a poor credit history when it comes to getting into housing," said Heather Dillashaw, director of the Asheville-Buncombe Homeless Initiative."It can be almost impossible to overcome that, and if you've had an eviction or an issue with public housing, your options are just incredibly limited.

"And of course people who become homeless almost always have poor credit," she said. "You don't fall into homelessness overnight, after paying bills on time and keeping up with rent. [Homeless] families have almost always made some tough choices."

"The end of the recession for one family may look very different for that of a homeless family," said Luke Heller, Buncombe County Schools homeless students liaison. "The hole is a lot deeper. We talk about children and families as a lagging indicator of an economic downturn, because families stretch their resources for longer and exhaust every option before they get to a place where they really ask for help, or are eligible for it.

"For families who are homeless, trying to get back on their feet may be experiencing challenges like access to child care, even if you qualify for vouchers. If you can't get child care how do you get to work if you get a job? There are still these very basic barriers."

And the inherent expenses that come with children — from childcare to school supplies to food and clothing — dig families deeper into debt than individuals, meaning that financial rock bottom comes later and hits harder than it might for single adults.

Dillashaw said childcare costs are one of the most, if not the most, significant barriers to climbing out of poverty.

Much of the family's savings have gone into paying for hotels on nights that Tiana and Lavar have to work, because they can't enter the shelter after 6 p.m.

"We can't get enough subsidy from anywhere to make up for the fact that we aren't paying a living wage, we just can't do it," Dillahsaw said.

"In a town like Asheville, we're a service industry town where low skill and no skill workers are making $8 an hour, that's $15,000 a year. We cannot make up for that gap. There's just no way for us to keep pace with that."

"We can address the middle class all we want, but that does nothing but push people who are already at the bottom further down," Dillashaw said. "That's just simple math. There's no rocket science behind that."

Tolls and trends

Statistically, the odds stacked against Zahmari, Aaliyah, Lavarion and Lavar extend to almost every aspect of their lives.

According to the National Center for Family Homelessness, homeless children are sick four times more often than other children. They have four times as many respiratory infections, have high rates of obesity because of nutritional deficiencies and have three times the rate of emotional and behavioral problems compared to non-homeless children.

By age 12, 83 percent of homeless children had been exposed to at least one serious violent event. Almost 25 percent have witnessed acts of violence within their own families.

Woods said it was only in recent years that more and more children started showing up in the shelter, an alarming trend he fears the shelter can't keep up with.

"We just can't build a place fast enough to keep up, the way things are going," Woods said. "And I hope we won't have to."

But the shelter beats the alternative, he said. Last year, he met a boy who came to the shelter and saw the bunks, and yelled, "I get a bed? I get to sleep in a bed!"

"He had never slept in a bed before, not ever," Woods said. "People think this is rock bottom, but that's a kid who wasn't even in the system yet. He wasn't on anybody's radar before he came here, and he had never slept in a bed before."

Cities the size of Asheville typically fall four to five years behind the bigger poverty and homelessness trends seen in larger cities like New York, which only recently has started to see results in keeping child homelessness rates at bay.

The shift in recent years, locally and across the country, has been to focus more resources on organizations that provide long-term, permanent housing rather than emergency services like shelters, Dillashaw said.

The city's 10-year plan to end homelessness is loosely based off the New York City Housing First Model.

Housing First, which is distinct and separate from "rapid re-housing" is a relatively recent model in human services, an alternative to a system of emergency shelter and transitional housing.

Rather than moving homeless individuals through different "levels" of housing, known as the Continuum of Care, Housing First moves the homeless individual or household immediately from the streets or homeless shelters into their own apartments.

The Department of Education estimates about 28,000 North Carolina students are homeless, but only about 22 percent of the state's school districts receive federal aid to assist with the problem.

"We can throw money at the problem all day long, and for some families it may only take $1,000 and they may even have an income to sustain them," Heller said. "Sometimes that fixes the problem, but more often than not that's just a band aid because there's something that tore it down in the first place. We need to get families into housing, but what then?"

Tiana said she hopes the family will find housing by the time the next school year starts and that Lavar will find a job, hopefully with better pay, closer to town.

The girls say they miss cooking and reading books and watching cartoons in bed with their parents the most — so a kitchen and a bedroom are their only real demands for a home.

"I like cooking breakfast," Zahmari said, when asked what she wants to do first when she gets a house. "I want to jump on the bed, too, but that's not allowed in our family.

"Mostly, I just want to read in bed with my mom and dad," she said. "We don't need, like, millions of dollars for that."

"I like having our own house, because it's safer," she said. "I like cooking breakfast, and being safe."
